title: Three Observations
author: Sam Altman
content:
Our mission is to ensure that AGI (Artificial General Intelligence) benefits all of humanity.Â 

Systems that start to point to AGI\* are coming into view, and so we think it's important to understand the moment we are in. AGI is a weakly defined term, but generally speaking we mean it to be a system that can tackle increasingly complex problems, at human level, in many fields.

People are tool-builders with an inherent drive to understand and create, which leads to the world getting better for all of us. Each new generation builds upon the discoveries of the generations before to create even more capable toolsâ€”electricity, the transistor, the computer, the internet, and soon AGI.

Over time, in fits and starts, the steady march of human innovation has brought previously unimaginable levels of prosperity and improvements to almost every aspect of people's lives.

In some sense, AGI is just another tool in this ever-taller scaffolding of human progress we are building together. In another sense, it is the beginning of something for which it's hard not to say "this time it's different"; the economic growth in front of us looks astonishing, and we can now imagine a world where we cure all diseases, have much more time to enjoy with our families, and can fully realize our creative potential.

In a decade, perhaps everyone on earth will be capable of accomplishing more than the most impactful person can today.

We continue to see rapid progress with AI development. Here are three observations about the economics of AI:

1\. **The intelligence of an AI model roughly equals the log of the resources used to train and run it.** These resources are chiefly training compute, data, and inference compute. It appears that you can spend arbitrary amounts of money and get continuous and predictable gains; the scaling laws that predict this are accurate over many orders of magnitude.

2\. **The cost to use a given level of AI falls about 10x every 12 months, and lower prices lead to much more use.** You can see this in the token cost from GPT-4 in early 2023 to GPT-4o in mid-2024, where the price per token dropped about 150x in that time period. Moore's law changed the world at 2x every 18 months; this is unbelievably stronger.Â 

3\. **The socioeconomic value of linearly increasing intelligence is super-exponential in nature.** A consequence of this is that we see no reason for exponentially increasing investment to stop in the near future.

If these three observations continue to hold true, the impacts on society will be significant.

We are now starting to roll out AI agents, which will eventually feel like virtual co-workers.

Let's imagine the case of a software engineering agent, which is an agent that we expect to be particularly important. Imagine that this agent will eventually be capable of doing most things a software engineer at a top company with a few years of experience could do, for tasks up to a couple of days long. It will not have the biggest new ideas, it will require lots of human supervision and direction, and it will be great at some things but surprisingly bad at others.

Still, imagine it as a real-but-relatively-junior virtual coworker. Now imagine 1,000 of them. Or 1 million of them. Now imagine such agents in every field of knowledge work.

In some ways, AI may turn out to be like the transistor economicallyâ€”a big scientific discovery that scales well and that seeps into almost every corner of the economy. We don't think much about transistors, or transistor companies, and the gains are very widely distributed. But we do expect our computers, TVs, cars, toys, and more to perform miracles.

The world will not change all at once; it never does. Life will go on mostly the same in the short run, and people in 2025 will mostly spend their time in the same way they did in 2024. We will still fall in love, create families, get in fights online, hike in nature, etc.

But the future will be coming at us in a way that is impossible to ignore, and the long-term changes to our society and economy will be huge. We will find new things to do, new ways to be useful to each other, and new ways to compete, but they may not look very much like the jobs of today.Â 

Agency, willfulness, and determination will likely be extremely valuable. Correctly deciding what to do and figuring out how to navigate an ever-changing world will have huge value; resilience and adaptability will be helpful skills to cultivate. AGI will be the biggest lever ever on human willfulness, and enable individual people to have more impact than ever before, not less.

We expect the impact of AGI to be uneven. Although some industries will change very little, scientific progress will likely be much faster than it is today; this impact of AGI may surpass everything else.

The price of many goods will eventually fall dramatically (right now, the cost of intelligence and the cost of energy constrain a lot of things), and the price of luxury goods and a few inherently limited resources like land may rise even more dramatically.

Technically speaking, the road in front of us looks fairly clear. But public policy and collective opinion on how we should integrate AGI into society matter a lot; one of our reasons for launching products early and often is to give society and the technology time to co-evolve.

AI will seep into all areas of the economy and society; we will expect everything to be smart. Many of us expect to need to give people more control over the technology than we have historically, including open-sourcing more, and accept that there is a balance between safety and individual empowerment that will require trade-offs.

While we never want to be reckless and there will likely be some major decisions and limitations related to AGI safety that will be unpopular, directionally, as we get closer to achieving AGI, we believe that trending more towards individual empowerment is important; the other likely path we can see is AI being used by authoritarian governments to control their population through mass surveillance and loss of autonomy.

Ensuring that the benefits of AGI are broadly distributed is critical. The historical impact of technological progress suggests that most of the metrics we care about (health outcomes, economic prosperity, etc.) get better on average and over the long-term, but increasing equality does not seem technologically determined and getting this right may require new ideas.

In particular, it does seem like the balance of power between capital and labor could easily get messed up, and this may require early intervention. We are open to strange-sounding ideas like giving some "compute budget" to enable everyone on Earth to use a lot of AI, but we can also see a lot of ways where just relentlessly driving the cost of intelligence as low as possible has the desired effect.

Anyone in 2035 should be able to marshall the intellectual capacity equivalent to everyone in 2025; everyone should have access to unlimited genius to direct however they can imagine. There is a great deal of talent right now without the resources to fully express itself, and if we change that, the resulting creative output of the world will lead to tremendous benefits for us all.

  
  
  

  

  

Thanks especially to Josh Achiam, Boaz Barak and Aleksander Madry for reviewing drafts of this.

\*By using the term AGI here, we aim to communicate clearly, and we do not intend to alter or interpret the definitions and processes that define our relationship with Microsoft. We fully expect to be partnered with Microsoft for the long term. This footnote seems silly, but on the other hand we know some journalists will try to get clicks by writing something silly so here we are pre-empting the sillinessâ€¦

First, I note that Sam Altman's 'Three Observations' is a high-level, forward-looking essay on the economic and societal implications of AGI, with a focus on the scaling properties of AI, the rapid decline in cost, and the super-exponential value of intelligence. The tone is optimistic, emphasizing broad-based prosperity, empowerment, and the potential for AGI to be a transformative tool akin to the transistor. 

Key themes include: (1) the predictability and continuity of AI scaling laws, (2) the dramatic reduction in the cost of intelligence, (3) the super-exponential value of increased intelligence, (4) the analogy to previous general-purpose technologies, (5) the uneven but ultimately positive distribution of benefits, (6) the importance of policy and societal adaptation, and (7) the risk of authoritarian misuse versus individual empowerment. 

From an EA perspective, the essay is notable for its focus on the positive-sum potential of AGI, but it is relatively light on concrete proposals, risk mitigation, or explicit discussion of existential risks. The author acknowledges the need for broad distribution of benefits and hints at possible interventions (e.g., compute budgets), but does not deeply engage with the most severe downside risks or the specifics of safety. 

The document is influential due to Altman's position, and its framing may shape public and policymaker attitudes. However, the lack of detailed analysis or actionable recommendations limits its direct tractability. The novelty is moderate: the economic scaling arguments are well-known in the AI community, but the public framing and emphasis on empowerment are distinctive. 

Potential negative impacts include: (a) underemphasizing catastrophic or existential risks, (b) encouraging rapid deployment without sufficient caution, (c) reinforcing techno-optimism that may crowd out more nuanced or safety-focused discourse. On the positive side, the essay could help steer the conversation toward broad benefit-sharing and individual empowerment, which are important from a welfare-maximization perspective. 

For the Fermi estimate, the direct impact is hard to quantify, but as a high-profile essay, it could influence the thinking of policymakers, funders, and the public. If it shifts the probability of positive-sum AGI deployment or broad benefit-sharing by even a small amount, the expected value could be substantial. However, if it also increases the probability of reckless deployment or neglect of safety, the net value could be lower or even negative. 

Overall, the essay is important for agenda-setting and public framing, but its lack of depth on risk and actionability constrains its expected impact relative to more technical or policy-oriented work.

# EA Impact Evaluation: 'Three Observations' by Sam Altman

## Executive Summary
Sam Altman's 'Three Observations' is a high-level reflection on the economic and societal implications of AGI, emphasizing the rapid scaling of AI capabilities, the dramatic reduction in costs, and the super-exponential value of intelligence. The essay frames AGI as both a continuation of humanity's tool-building tradition and a potentially unprecedented lever for prosperity and empowerment. While the piece is optimistic and influential, it is light on concrete risk mitigation or actionable policy recommendations. **Estimated impact: $500Kâ€“$2M equivalent value (90% CI), with notable strengths in agenda-setting and public framing, but limitations in tractability and risk coverage.**

## Framework Analysis
- **Importance (8/10):** The essay addresses AGI, arguably the most consequential technology of the century, with implications for billions of people and the long-term future. Its framing could influence key decision-makers and public attitudes. However, the lack of technical depth or policy specificity tempers its leverage.
- **Neglectedness (5/10):** The broad themes (AI scaling, economic impact) are widely discussed, but the specific framing around empowerment and benefit-sharing is less common. As a public essay by a leading figure, it fills some informational gaps but is not uniquely neglected.
- **Tractability (4/10):** The essay is not actionable; it offers few concrete steps or policy proposals. Its main effect is likely to be indirect, via agenda-setting and influencing discourse.
- **Novelty (5/10):** The economic scaling arguments are well-known, but the emphasis on individual empowerment and compute budgets is relatively fresh in public discourse. The essay does not introduce new analytical methods or technical insights.

## Fermi Estimate of Expected Impact
- **Parameters:**
  - Audience: ~1M influential readers (policymakers, technologists, funders)
  - Probability of shifting attitudes/policy: 0.1â€“1%
  - Value per marginal shift (e.g., toward broad benefit-sharing): $10Mâ€“$100M (if realized)
  - Probability of negative effects (e.g., increased recklessness): 0.05â€“0.2%, with similar magnitude
- **Calculation:**
  - Positive: 1M Ã— 0.1% Ã— $10M = $10M expected value (upper bound)
  - Negative: 1M Ã— 0.05% Ã— -$10M = -$5M expected value (upper bound)
  - Net: $500Kâ€“$2M (90% CI), reflecting high uncertainty and indirect effects
- **Benchmarks:** Comparable to high-impact public advocacy or agenda-setting pieces, but below technical safety research or direct policy interventions.

## Cause Area Analysis
- **Fits within:** Longtermism, AI safety, meta/advocacy
- **Comparison:** Less direct than technical safety work (e.g., reducing x-risk by 1 in 10,000), but potentially more influential than typical op-eds due to Altman's stature.

## Key Value Drivers
- **Strengths:** Agenda-setting, public framing, emphasis on broad benefit-sharing and empowerment
- **Limitations:** Lack of actionable recommendations, underemphasis on catastrophic/existential risks, potential to encourage reckless optimism
- **Uncertainties:** Actual influence on policy and public attitudes; balance of positive vs. negative effects

## Recommendations
- **Impact could be increased by:** Including more concrete policy proposals, explicit discussion of existential risks, and actionable steps for broad benefit-sharing and safety.

## Overall Grade: C+ (Score: 65)
The essay is a valuable contribution to public discourse on AGI, with moderate expected impact primarily through agenda-setting. Its influence is limited by a lack of depth on risk and tractability.

He then extrapolates to a world of ubiquitous, cheap, junior-level AI agents, and speculates about societal and economic impacts, with a nod to policy and safety concerns.

Now, evaluating the reasoning:
- The document is almost entirely focused on economic and social impacts, with only glancing reference to safety or existential risk. There is no substantive engagement with alignment, control, or the possibility of catastrophic failure modes. This is a glaring omission, given the stakes.

For example, the scaling laws may break down, or the cost curves may hit physical or algorithmic bottlenecks. More importantly, the focus on economic scaling ignores the alignment problem: the fact that more powerful systems may be less predictable and less controllable.

## High-Level Analysis of Sam Altman's 'Three Observations'

### 1. Core Claims and Reasoning Quality
Sam Altman's essay is a paradigmatic example of the techno-optimist narrative that pervades Silicon Valley: AGI is framed as the next step in a long line of human tool-building, promising supercharged economic growth and widespread prosperity. The three 'observations'â€”logarithmic scaling of intelligence with resources, rapidly falling costs, and super-exponential value from incremental intelligenceâ€”are plausible extrapolations from current trends, but are presented with a level of confidence that is not epistemically justified given the deep uncertainties involved.

Critically, the essay almost entirely omits the central technical and existential risks posed by AGI. There is no substantive engagement with the alignment problem, the possibility of catastrophic failure, or the qualitative discontinuity that AGI represents relative to previous technologies. The analogy to the transistor is invoked, but the crucial differenceâ€”that AGI is an optimizer with potentially unbounded capability and misaligned goalsâ€”is ignored. This is a classic case of failing to distinguish between the map (our analogies and expectations) and the territory (the actual properties of AGI).

### 2. Cognitive Biases and Reasoning Errors
The essay is riddled with familiar cognitive biases:
- **Progress Bias / Whig History:** The assumption that technological progress is inherently beneficial and will continue to improve human welfare, despite the lack of Bayesian updating on the evidence of existential risk.
- **Anthropomorphism:** Describing AI agents as 'junior coworkers' risks misleading readers about their actual cognitive architecture and motivational structure.
- **Overconfidence:** The claim that 'the road in front of us looks fairly clear' is not justified given the profound uncertainties around AGI development and alignment.
- **Goodhart's Law Neglect:** There is no recognition that optimizing for proxies (e.g., economic value, intelligence metrics) can lead to catastrophic misalignment.

### 3. Implications for AI Alignment
From an alignment perspective, the essay is deeply inadequate. It treats AGI as a tool to be distributed and democratized, rather than as a potentially adversarial optimizer whose goals may diverge from human values. The only nod to safety is a vague reference to 'trade-offs' between safety and empowerment, with no concrete proposals or recognition of the technical difficulty of alignment. This is a fundamental error: the central problem is not access or distribution, but control and value alignment.

### 4. Broader Themes and Recommendations
The essay exemplifies the institutional and epistemic inadequacy that has characterized much of the mainstream AI discourse. It fails to grapple with the core technical challenges, downplays existential risk, and substitutes economic optimism for rigorous analysis. A more adequate approach would foreground alignment as the central challenge, acknowledge the deep technical uncertainty, and avoid anthropomorphic analogies. It would also explicitly discuss the risk of catastrophic failure, not just economic disruption.

**Probabilistic Assessment:** I assign >90% probability that this essay would mislead a non-expert audience about the true risks and challenges of AGI, and <10% probability that it would help advance serious alignment discourse.

## Quantitative Forecaster's Analysis of "Three Observations" by Sam Altman

### 1. High-Level Assessment
Sam Altman's essay is a forward-looking meditation on the trajectory of AGI and its likely economic and societal impacts. The document is notable for its blend of technical optimism, historical analogy, and explicit concern for equitable distribution. Altman frames AGI as both a continuation of humanity's tool-building tradition and a potential discontinuityâ€”"this time it's different"â€”with the promise of super-exponential economic value and transformative societal change.

### 2. Key Themes and Patterns
- **Scaling Laws and Predictable Progress:** The essay highlights that AI intelligence scales logarithmically with resources, and that cost reductions are outpacing even Moore's Law. This is supported by the cited 150x drop in token cost from GPT-4 to GPT-4o in about 18 months. If this trend continues, the marginal cost of intelligence could approach zero for many applications within a decade.
- **Super-Exponential Value Creation:** Altman posits that even linear increases in AI capability can yield super-exponential socioeconomic value, suggesting that the economic impact of AGI could dwarf previous technological revolutions. This is a bold claim, but it aligns with the observed network effects and combinatorial innovation seen in past general-purpose technologies.
- **Distributional and Policy Concerns:** The essay is unusually explicit about the risks of unequal access and the need for proactive policy. Altman floats ideas like universal compute budgets and stresses the importance of individual empowerment over centralized control, especially in the face of potential authoritarian misuse.
- **Incremental but Inevitable Change:** While the long-term impacts are framed as enormous, Altman is careful to note that short-term societal rhythms will persist, and that technological diffusion is always uneven and gradual. This is a calibrated view, consistent with historical patterns of technological adoption.

### 3. Quantitative Forecasting Perspective
From a forecasting standpoint, the essay provides several concrete, testable claims:
- **AI Cost Trajectory:** If the cost per token continues to drop by 10x every 12 months, by 2030 the cost could be orders of magnitude lower than today. However, physical and economic limits may slow this trend.
- **AGI Timeline:** The suggestion that "anyone in 2035 should be able to marshall the intellectual capacity equivalent to everyone in 2025" is a strong claim about the pace of progress and diffusion. Historical reference classes (e.g., internet, electricity) suggest that such diffusion is possible but not guaranteed, especially given regulatory and infrastructural bottlenecks.
- **Economic Impact:** The claim of super-exponential value is ambitious. While plausible in the short run due to network effects and automation, diminishing returns and societal friction could moderate the long-term impact.

### 4. Key Uncertainties and Reference Classes
- **Technical Uncertainty:** Will scaling laws and cost reductions continue at the current pace?
- **Policy and Distribution:** Will access be broad or concentrated? Will regulatory responses slow or accelerate diffusion?
- **Societal Adaptation:** How quickly will labor markets, education, and institutions adapt?

Reference classes include the adoption curves of electricity, the internet, and the transistor, as well as the economic impact of general-purpose technologies.

### 5. Final Perspective
Altman's essay is a well-calibrated, optimistic, but not utopian vision. It is strongest when it grounds its claims in historical analogy and explicit metrics (e.g., cost per token), and most speculative when projecting super-exponential value and universal access. For forecasters, the key is to track the empirical validity of the scaling laws, cost curves, and diffusion rates, while remaining alert to policy and societal feedback loops that could accelerate or impede progress.

# Bias Assessment of "Three Observations" by Sam Altman

## 1. Executive Summary

Sam Altman's essay presents a highly optimistic vision of AGI, emphasizing its potential to benefit all of humanity and drive unprecedented economic and social progress. While the document is thoughtful and acknowledges some challenges, it exhibits several notable biases, particularly optimism bias, selection bias, and omission bias. The framing is largely techno-utopian, with limited engagement with counterarguments or historical examples of technological disruption that led to negative or uneven outcomes. The authorâ€™s position as a leading AI executive introduces potential motivated reasoning and authority bias, as well as a tendency to frame the narrative in ways that support his organizational mission and worldview.

## 2. Quantitative Bias Scores (1-10)

- **Optimism Bias:** 8/10
- **Selection Bias:** 7/10
- **Omission Bias:** 7/10
- **Authority Bias:** 6/10
- **Base Rate Neglect:** 6/10
- **Narrative Fallacy:** 6/10
- **Status Quo Bias:** 5/10
- **Survivorship Bias:** 5/10
- **In-group/Out-group Bias:** 4/10
- **Planning Fallacy:** 4/10

## 3. Most Significant Examples of Bias

- **Optimism Bias:** The essay consistently highlights positive outcomes (e.g., curing all diseases, universal empowerment) while downplaying or omitting detailed discussion of risks, failures, or negative externalities.
- **Selection Bias:** The historical analogies (transistor, internet) are chosen to support the narrative of inevitable, widely distributed progress, ignoring examples where technology exacerbated inequality or caused harm.
- **Omission Bias:** Risks such as mass unemployment, misuse of AGI, or catastrophic failure are only briefly mentioned or implied, not explored in depth.
- **Authority Bias:** The authorâ€™s position and the mention of expert reviewers may lend undue weight to the arguments, potentially discouraging critical scrutiny.
- **Base Rate Neglect:** The assumption that AGI will follow the same trajectory as past technologies overlooks the unique risks and uncertainties associated with AGI.

## 4. Prioritized Recommendations for Improvement

1. **Explicitly Address Risks:** Include a more balanced discussion of potential negative outcomes, drawing on historical examples where technology led to harm or increased inequality.
2. **Engage with Counterarguments:** Present and respond to common critiques or concerns about AGI, including those from outside the AI industry.
3. **Provide Empirical Evidence:** Support claims with data or references where possible, especially regarding economic impacts and scaling laws.
4. **Clarify Distribution Mechanisms:** Offer concrete proposals for ensuring broad distribution of AGI benefits, rather than relying on historical trends.
5. **Acknowledge Uncertainty:** Recognize the limits of prediction and the possibility of unforeseen consequences.

## 5. Limitations of the Analysis

- The analysis is based solely on the text provided and does not account for external context or unpublished drafts.
- Some biases may be inferred rather than explicit, given the high-level and speculative nature of the essay.
- The assessment does not include a comprehensive review of all possible counterarguments or alternative perspectives.

In a decade, perhaps everyone on earth will be capable of accomplishing more than the most impactful person can today.

comments.title: Anchoring Effect in AI Scaling Laws
comments.description: The statement that 'the intelligence of an AI model roughly equals the log of the resources used to train and run it' anchors the reader to a specific quantitative relationship, potentially overstating the predictability of AI progress. This *anchoring effect* may bias readers toward believing in continuous, predictable gains, despite possible diminishing returns or paradigm shifts. The author could discuss exceptions or uncertainties in scaling laws.

highlight.quotedText: The intelligence of an AI model roughly equals the log of the resources used to train and run it.** These resources are chiefly training compute, data, and inference compute. It appears that you can spend arbitrary amounts of money and get continuous and predictable gains; the scaling laws that predict this are accurate over many orders of magnitude.

comments.title: Goodhart's Law and Metric Over-Optimization
comments.description: The focus on metrics like 'price per token' and 'cost to use a given level of AI' risks falling into *Goodhart's Law*: 'When a measure becomes a target, it ceases to be a good measure.' Over-optimizing for cost or performance metrics can lead to unintended consequences, such as neglecting safety or ethical considerations. The author could acknowledge the limitations of using such metrics as proxies for overall progress.

highlight.quotedText: You can see this in the token cost from GPT-4 in early 2023 to GPT-4o in mid-2024, where the price per token dropped about 150x in that time period. Moore's law changed the world at 2x every 18 months; this is unbelievably stronger.

comments.title: Selection Bias in AI Use Cases
comments.description: The example of a 'software engineering agent' as a representative AI agent may reflect *selection bias*, focusing on a high-skill, high-demand field. This may not generalize to other professions or contexts, especially those with less structured tasks or lower digital infrastructure. The author could broaden the discussion to include diverse fields and acknowledge where AI may be less applicable.

highlight.quotedText:
Let's imagine the case of a software engineering agent, which is an agent that we expect to be particularly important. Imagine that this agent will eventually be capable of doing most things a software engineer at a top company with a few years of experience could do, for tasks up to a couple of days long. It will not have the biggest new ideas, it will require lots of human supervision and direction, and it will be great at some things but surprisingly bad at others.

Still, imagine it as a real-but-relatively-junior virtual coworker. Now imagine 1,000 of them. Or 1 million of them. Now imagine such agents in every field of knowledge work.

comments.title: Narrative Fallacy in Economic Analogies
comments.description: Comparing AI to the transistor and suggesting that its economic impact will be similarly positive is an example of the *narrative fallacy*. This constructs a compelling story based on selective analogies, which may oversimplify complex realities. The analogy may not hold due to differences in scale, risk, and societal impact. The author could provide more nuanced comparisons and discuss where the analogy may break down.

highlight.quotedText: In some ways, AI may turn out to be like the transistor economicallyâ€”a big scientific discovery that scales well and that seeps into almost every corner of the economy. We don't think much about transistors, or transistor companies, and the gains are very widely distributed. But we do expect our computers, TVs, cars, toys, and more to perform miracles.

comments.title: Status Quo Bias in Short-Term Predictions
comments.description: The claim that 'life will go on mostly the same in the short run' reflects *status quo bias*, assuming that near-term changes will be minimal despite the introduction of transformative technology. This may underprepare audiences for rapid or disruptive shifts. The author could discuss scenarios where short-term impacts are more significant.

highlight.quotedText: The world will not change all at once; it never does. Life will go on mostly the same in the short run, and people in 2025 will mostly spend their time in the same way they did in 2024. We will still fall in love, create families, get in fights online, hike in nature, etc.

comments.title: False Consensus Effect in Value Judgments
comments.description: The text assumes that 'agency, willfulness, and determination will likely be extremely valuable' and that 'resilience and adaptability will be helpful skills to cultivate.' This may reflect the *false consensus effect*, projecting the author's values onto the broader population. Different cultures or individuals may prioritize other traits. The author could acknowledge alternative perspectives on what skills or values will be important in an AGI-driven world.

highlight.quotedText: Agency, willfulness, and determination will likely be extremely valuable. Correctly deciding what to do and figuring out how to navigate an ever-changing world will have huge value; resilience and adaptability will be helpful skills to cultivate. AGI will be the biggest lever ever on human willfulness, and enable individual people to have more impact than ever before, not less.

comments.title: Out-Group Homogeneity Bias in Political Scenarios
comments.description: The text contrasts 'individual empowerment' with 'authoritarian governments' using AI for mass surveillance. This dichotomy may reflect *out-group homogeneity bias*, oversimplifying the motives and diversity of non-democratic societies. It risks alienating readers from different political contexts and may overlook nuanced policy approaches. The author could discuss a broader range of governance models and acknowledge complexities in global AI deployment.

highlight.quotedText:
the other likely path we can see is AI being used by authoritarian governments to control their population through mass surveillance and loss of autonomy.

Ensuring that the benefits of AGI are broadly distributed is critical.

comments.title: System Justification Bias in Technological Progress
comments.description: The statement that 'the historical impact of technological progress suggests that most of the metrics we care about... get better on average and over the long-term' reflects *system justification bias*. It assumes that existing systems will naturally adapt to and benefit from AGI, potentially overlooking the need for systemic change or the risk of exacerbating inequalities. The author could discuss historical cases where technology increased inequality or required major policy interventions.

highlight.quotedText:
The historical impact of technological progress suggests that most of the metrics we care about (health outcomes, economic prosperity, etc.) get better on average and over the long-term, but increasing equality does not seem technologically determined and getting this right may require new ideas.

In particular, it does seem like the balance of power between capital and labor could easily get messed up, and this may require early intervention.

comments.title: Planning Fallacy in Timelines
comments.description: The suggestion that 'anyone in 2035 should be able to marshall the intellectual capacity equivalent to everyone in 2025' may reflect the *planning fallacy*, underestimating the time and complexity required for such transformative change. This could set unrealistic expectations for policymakers and the public. The author could discuss potential obstacles and the historical tendency for major projects to take longer than anticipated.

highlight.quotedText: Anyone in 2035 should be able to marshall the intellectual capacity equivalent to everyone in 2025; everyone should have access to unlimited genius to direct however they can imagine. There is a great deal of talent right now without the resources to fully express itself, and if we change that, the resulting creative output of the world will lead to tremendous benefits for us all.

comments.title: Authority Bias in Reviewer Acknowledgment
comments.description: The explicit thanks to well-known AI researchers for reviewing drafts may invoke *authority bias*, encouraging readers to accept the arguments based on the stature of the reviewers rather than the merits of the content. While expert review is valuable, the author could clarify the scope of the reviewers' input and encourage critical engagement from all readers.

highlight.quotedText: Thanks especially to Josh Achiam, Boaz Barak and Aleksander Madry for reviewing drafts of this.

comments.title: Reactance Bias in Footnote Commentary
comments.description: The footnote preemptively dismisses journalists as seeking 'clicks by writing something silly,' which may trigger *reactance bias*â€”readers may resist or distrust the author's message due to perceived defensiveness or antagonism. This could undermine the credibility of the text among media professionals or critical readers. The author could adopt a more neutral tone and engage constructively with potential critics.

highlight.quotedText: This footnote seems silly, but on the other hand we know some journalists will try to get clicks by writing something silly so here we are pre-empting the sillinessâ€¦

comments.title: Omission Bias in Addressing Risks
comments.description: Throughout the document, there is little discussion of concrete risks, failure modes, or negative externalities associated with AGI. This reflects *omission bias*, where potential downsides are underrepresented. This may lead audiences to underestimate the importance of safety, ethics, and governance. The author could include a dedicated section on risks and mitigation strategies.

highlight.quotedText:
While we never want to be reckless and there will likely be some major decisions and limitations related to AGI safety that will be unpopular, directionally, as we get closer to achieving AGI, we believe that trending more towards individual empowerment is important; the other likely path we can see is AI being used by authoritarian governments to control their population through mass surveillance and loss of autonomy.

Ensuring that the benefits of AGI are broadly distributed is critical.
